data.meta_description: Warm up those â€˜80s dance moves and get ready to cut loose to the best songs from â€™80s movies
data.text:
No decade combined music and movies quite like the â€™80s. Sure, the 1960s has a handful of songs still used to signal â€˜the â€™60s, maaaanâ€™, and the 1990s produced some classic soundtracks. But try to imagine any John Hughes film without the new wave hits that accompanied them. Or Ghostbusters without Ray Parker Jr.â€™s theme song. Or Michael J Fox skating through Hill Valley without Huey Lewis crooning about â€˜The Power of Loveâ€™. And shoot, donâ€™t even get us started on Purple Rain.

Suffice to say, an â€™80s movie canâ€™t be considered a true â€™80s movie if the soundtrack isnâ€™t banging. But what are the absolute best songs from â€™80s movies? Everyone has their personal favorites: the ones that instantly conjure memories (or at least fantasies) of spraying on Aquanet, throwing on some spandex and heading to the multiplex in your Delorean. Here, though, we present the ultimate, canonical, indisputable ranking of the most radical songs from â€™80s movies. And in order to keep it strictly â€™80s, we limited the list only to songs actually made in the decade â€“ so no â€˜Stand By Meâ€™ or â€˜Day-Oâ€™, as much as weâ€™d want to include them.

Written by Michael Chen, Brent DiCrescenzo, Andrew Frisicano, Sophie Harris, Oliver Keens, James Manning, Tristan Parker, Amy Plitt, Joshua Rothkopf, Hank Shteamer, Matthew Singer, Steve Smith, Sarah Theeboom and Kate Wertheimer.

50. â€œBatdanceâ€ by Prince (Batman, 1989)

â€œBatdanceâ€ is to the Purple Oneâ€™s playful soundtrack as the trailer is to the movie. In this three-part album closer, Prince dices and splices clips from the movie and bits of his own songs, whipping up a funky hybrid of house music and New Jack Swingâ€”complete with a hair-raising, hair-metal wank solo. Itâ€™s dance-floor serious, but with all the camp, color and pow! whomp! of a 1960s DC Comics panel. The opening third revisits â€œThe Future,â€ a cut that 25 years later still sounds on the 22nd-century horizon. But itâ€™s part two, the Vicki Vale section, that captures our hearts and booties, as the little sex elf admits, â€œOo yeah, oo yeah, I wanna busâ€™ that body.â€â€”Brent DiCrescenzo

49. â€œKrush Groovinâ€™â€ by Krush Groove All-Stars (Krush Groove, 1985)

White kids in the suburbs were beat-boxing and laying cardboard boxes in their driveways for break dancing before Licensed to Ill came along. Breakinâ€™ and Beat Street took budding New York hip-hop culture to middle America in 1984. A year later, Krush Groove prematurely mythologized the rise of Def Jam Recordsâ€”a year before the Beastie Boys even released a record. This jam was better than anything on those other two soundtracks, bringing together rap icons Run-D.M.C., Kurtis Blow, Fat Boys and, uh, Sheila E., introducing so many youth to rhyming and scratching. Parentsâ€™ turntables would be permanently damaged soon thereafter.â€”Brent DiCrescenzo

48. â€œCat People (Putting Out Fire)â€ by David Bowie (Cat People, 1982)

Wisely, as he did with â€œAbsolute Beginners,â€ Bowie ignores the plot of this neon-lit remake of a French thrillerâ€”an extended masculine metaphor in which sexual women transform into predatory felines. Instead, he wails about fire and gasoline. Decades later, Quentin Tarantino would apply the song more literally in Inglourious Basterds, when MÃ©lanie Laurent burns down a Parisian cinema full of Nazis. It was a cinematic rescue mission, saving this fantastic, Moroder-produced track (him again) from its origin.â€”Brent DiCrescenzo

47. â€œThe Heat Is Onâ€ by Glenn Frey (Beverly Hills Cop, 1984)

What do the Eagles and krautrock have in common? Not much, admittedly, though those two worlds copulate to make what sounds like a baby Pointer Sister blowing a yakety sax in â€œThe Heat Is On.â€ The classically trained Harold Faltermeyer, who composed Beverly Hillsâ€™ â€œAxel Fâ€ (not to mention the â€œTop Gun Anthemâ€), started out as Giorgio Moroderâ€™s keyboardist before going on to totally corner the market in buddy-cop-movie scoring. Frey, eternally in Don Henleyâ€™s shadow, tried to make his name solo in soundtrack work, but ended up lifting ideas from either Loggins (this song) or Collins (Miami Viceâ€™s â€œYou Belong to the Cityâ€). Maybe thatâ€™s what he meant by â€œSmugglerâ€™s Blues.â€â€”Brent DiCrescenzo

Advertising

46. â€˜Moving In Stereoâ€™ by the Cars (Fast Times at Ridgemont High, 1982)

Amy Heckerlingâ€™s awesome (totally awesome) teen comedy contains several memorable needle-drops - Jennifer Jason Leigh losing her virginity to â€˜Somebodyâ€™s Babyâ€™ by Jackson Browne, hapless romantic Mark â€˜Ratâ€™ Ratner screwing up his buddyâ€™s advice and playing the wrong Led Zeppelin album on a first date - but the one thatâ€™s burned into the brains of every teenage boy who came across the movie on cable involves Phoebe Cates emerging in slo-mo from a swimming pool. â€˜Moving In Stereoâ€™ is the weirdest song on the Carsâ€™ flawless first album, all icy synths and creeping groove, but itâ€™s a perfectly lascivious soundtrack for single, successful guy Judge Reinholdâ€™s porny hallucinations, as he, uh, â€˜admiresâ€™ his younger sisterâ€™s best friend from the bathroom window. The songâ€™s even more impactful when it abruptly cuts off and the real Cates walks in on him mid-fantasy. Doesnâ€™t anybody fucking knock anymore?!â€”Matthew Singer

45. â€œHazy Shade of Winterâ€ by the Bangles (Less than Zero, 1987)

The Bangles blew up with the help of Prince and studio-pop novelties like â€œWalk Like an Egyptian.â€ But a Simon & Garfunkel cover was hardly out of left field for the L.A. girl group. The band grew out of the Paisley Underground, where Susanna Hoffs cut her teeth singing folky knee-weakeners like â€œFlying on the Ground Is Wrong,â€ originally a Buffalo Springfield tune. However, this Rick Rubinâ€“produced remake is tense arena rock, glittering like Poison rubbed in suntan oil. Still, thereâ€™s a darkness lurking underneath the four-part harmonies. Perfect for a movie of pretty college-age preppies with junk, gigoloing and emptiness swimming behind their pearly teeth.â€”Brent DiCrescenzo

Advertising

44. â€œInto the Grooveâ€ by Madonna (Desperately Seeking Susan, 1985)

Could this be the mightiest meta dance anthem of all time? The 1985 film that spawned it now seems like a kitschy time capsule of Koch-era NYC, but Madonnaâ€™s synth-spangled come-on still destroys in just about any setting. â€œWhen I was writing it, I was sitting in a fourth-floor walk-up on Avenue B,â€ Madonna told Time, â€œand there was this gorgeous Puerto Rican boy sitting across from me that I wanted to go out on a date with.â€ To the stud in question, if youâ€™re reading this: Youâ€™re our hero.â€”Hank Shteamer

43. â€œRhythm of the Nightâ€ by DeBarge (The Last Dragon, 1985)

One imagines Motown boss Berry Gordy, coproducer of The Last Dragon, had commerce in mind when he cobbled together the filmâ€™s soundtrack of in-house acts (Smokey Robinson, the Temptations, Stevie Wonder), but that fact doesnâ€™t make it any less of a top-notch collection. Between glowing martial artists and Afro-and-football-pad-sporting villains, family band DeBarge got one of the biggest onscreen bumps, with an extended clip for â€œRhythm of the Nightâ€ played on one of the characterâ€™s music-video shows. The calypso beat and Jheri curl may be reminiscent of Lionel Richieâ€™s â€œAll Night Long,â€ but the spectacular falsetto peak is all DeBarge.â€”Andrew Frisicano

Advertising

42. â€œLetâ€™s Hear It for the Boyâ€ by Deniece Williams (Footloose, 1984)

Williams, a former backup singer for Stevie Wonder from Gary, Indiana, comes off as a Disney cutie pie in this middle-school sock-hop staple (if you didnâ€™t grow up in this era, trust us). It was produced by funk fusionist George Duke, the man who brought the keytar to jazz, like a whoopee cushion at a political symposium. The sleeper hit of the Footloose soundtrack, it took No. 1 on the Billboard charts for two weeks, outperforming Ann Wilson and Mike Renoâ€™s â€œAlmost Paradise,â€ Bonnie Tylerâ€™s â€œHolding Out for a Heroâ€ and, er, Shalamarâ€™s â€œDancing in the Sheets.â€ Sure, she couldnâ€™t quite match Loggins, but who could?â€”Brent DiCrescenzo

41. â€œI Can Dream About Youâ€ by Dan Hartman (Streets of Fire, 1984)

You wouldn't expect a gritty Willem Dafoeâ€“Diane Lane action musical to spawn a soft-rock warhorse, but hey, this is the â€™80s we're talking about. Blues-steeped Pennsylvania songsmith Hartman offered the tune to Hall & Oatesâ€”which accounts for the silky soul-pop sheen of the finished productâ€”but the Philly hit makers, then at the tail end of their commercial peak, turned him down. All the better for the authorâ€”and for the Sorels, the hot-stepping neo-Motown combo that performed the song onscreen.â€”Hank Shteamer

40. â€œWe Donâ€™t Need Another Hero (Thunderdome)â€ by Tina Turner (Mad Max Beyond Thunderdome, 1985)

Could there be anyone more perfect to sing the opening lines of this song than Tina Turner? â€œOut from the ruins,â€ she rasps. â€œOut from the wreckageâ€¦ Canâ€™t make the same mistakes this time.â€ Of course, in the context of postapocalyptic desert fantasy Mad Max Beyond Thunderdome, Turner is singing as Aunty Entity, ruler of outlaw outpost Bartertown. But Turnerâ€™s real-life story as a true soul survivor imbues the song and her performance in the movie with something truly extraordinary. Hail, warrior queen!â€”Sophie Harris

39. â€œAgainst All Odds (Take a Look at Me Now)â€ by Phil Collins (Against All Odds, 1984)

Thereâ€™s a certain class of song within this listâ€”those soundtrack tunes that far outperformed their movies. You donâ€™t realize that this most powerful and ballady of power ballads is from a Jeff Bridges cheese-noir flick until you go searching for it on No Jacket Required. We have become so used to terrible romances lifting their titles from established songs, we forget that some songs became established via terrible romances. A leftover from his 1981 solo debut, â€œAgainst All Oddsâ€ gave the former Genesis man his first American No. 1 hit in 1984.â€”Brent DiCrescenzo

Advertising

38. â€œHungry Eyesâ€ by Eric Carmen (Dirty Dancing, 1987)

Sure, the rhymes are suspect (â€œHungry eyes/I feel the magic between you and Iâ€). And the grammar is downright deplorable (same line: â€œbetween you and Iâ€). But this isnâ€™t about rules. Rules are what brought us to this sticky predicament in the Catskills, summer 1963. No, this is about unleashing the carnal, forbidden passion that rebellious hip-shaker Patrick Swayze and good-girl-going-bad Jennifer Grey feel, locked in a gaze as they tighten their frame on the dance floor. All by himself, underrated hit-maker Eric Carmen delivers the magic and then some.â€”Michael Chen

37. â€œTogether in Electric Dreamsâ€ by Philip Oakey & Giorgio Moroder (Electric Dreams, 1984)

Soundtracking the mood of a film that depicts a lighthearted love triangle among a man, a woman and a computer isnâ€™t easy, but the Human Leagueâ€™s Phil Oakey and Giorgio Moroder nailed it here. The upbeat, sunny synth chords, bouncy computer rhythms and Oakeyâ€™s soaring vocals will force a smile even if youâ€™ve just been dumped by both your human partner and your laptop.â€”Tristan Parker

Advertising

36. â€œThe NeverEnding Storyâ€ by Limahl (The NeverEnding Story, 1984)

The aural equivalent of soaring through clouds on Falkorâ€™s back, this never-ending theme song glides from fade-in to fade-out with almost no buildup in between. But who needs structure when you have that divine descending vocal run floating over impressionist washes of synth? That Midas of pop music, Giorgio Moroder, had his golden fingers all over this track, so it should surprise no one that its English and French versions topped the charts all over Europe that year. At the start of the video clip, U.K. singer Limahl mugs into the camera with a smoldering seriousness that would be laughable if he didnâ€™t also have the mullet to pull it off.â€”Sarah Theeboom

35. â€œLet the River Runâ€ by Carly Simon (Working Girl, 1988)

Melanie Griffith is your average outer-boroughs girl dreaming of making it in the world of teased hair, cinch-waisted trench coats and capes that is 1980s Wall Street. She commutes by boat to Manhattan, as Carly Simon sings of silver cities rising in the fog with enough pomp to make the Staten Island Ferry seem like a golden steamship full of salt-of-the-earth immigrants arriving at Ellis Island. Simonâ€™s semispiritual mumbo jumbo is all â€œWe Are the Worldâ€ chorus, all the time, set to a pseudo-African rhythm in slo-mo. Itâ€™s a chorus as wide and high as Sigourney Weaverâ€™s shoulder pads, with that epic octave jump. Thereâ€™s no way Simon could have intended the lump in the throat that arrives when seeing the World Trade Center in the video, but itâ€™s there all the same.â€”Brent DiCrescenzo

Advertising

34. â€œThe Goonies â€˜Râ€™ Good Enoughâ€ by Cyndi Lauper (The Goonies, 1985)

Arrr, mateys, no treasure hunt be complete without this spunky Cyndi Lauper hit accompanying the swashbuckling exploits. A perfect musical representation of the plucky â€œGoonies never say die!â€ spirit, â€œGood Enoughâ€ also gave us a two-part gem of a video that stars a treasure trove of â€™80s notablesâ€”Mikey, Chunk, Data and the rest of the Goonies gang; Lauperâ€™s adopted WWF wrestling family (the Fabulous Moolah, the Iron Sheik, â€œRowdyâ€ Roddy Piper); Goonies creator and producer Steven Spielberg; and Lauperâ€™s friends, a then-unknown all-girl band called the Bangles. When adventureâ€™s afoot, put on your â€œslick shoes,â€ fire up this track, do the â€œTruffle Shuffleâ€ and, no matter what, donâ€™t go up Troyâ€™s bucket!â€”Michael Chen

33. â€œPut a Little Love in Your Heartâ€ by Annie Lennox & Al Green (Scrooged, 1988)

Originally a sweet and cooing hit for Jackie DeShannon in 1968, this gooey, soulful number was given a full-on â€™80s power remake for the movie Scrooged, performed by a twosome that only a movie studio could dream up: Annie Lennox and Al Green. The clap-along gospel rhythm and showboating vocal coda even managed to put a smile on Bill Murrayâ€™s miserly face in the movie.â€”Oliver Keens

Advertising

32. â€œAbsolute Beginnersâ€ by David Bowie (Absolute Beginners, 1986)

Directors, beware. When you commission Bowie to pen your cinematic theme, he is more likely to follow his own muse. â€œAbsolute Beginnersâ€ is the Thin White Duke at a midlife crisis, reflecting on his own past. It is a sad and fatalistic song, about starting over while knowing that you cannot. Bowie gave his session players vague commands, like â€œThink greenâ€ and â€œSound Brazilian.â€ The result was a melancholic recasting of the jazz-club rock & roll of Aladdin Sane. Bowie, then 39, casually leans up against the stiff groove as if it were a streetlight. The verses languidly hold on for 40 barsâ€”Bowie never wants it to end, but knows that it must. This would be his last commercial chart hit, almost willfully. God knows what it has to do with Julian Templeâ€™s too bright and bowdlerized musical film of 1950s mores. The movie bombed, partly because it could hardly live up to the expectations set forth by its brilliant theme.â€”Brent DiCrescenzo

31. â€˜9 To 5â€™ by Dolly Parton (9 to 5, 1980)

Dolly Partonâ€™s ascent from beloved country star to American saint began with a movie that likely wouldâ€™ve been forgotten without her. 9 to 5 is an odd duck, a feminist screwball comedy about three women who kidnap their chauvinist boss in order to implement more employee-friendly policies at their office. It co-stars Jane Fonda and Lily Tomlin, but itâ€™s remembered primarily for two things: Partonâ€™s acting debut as a â€˜smarter than she looksâ€™ receptionist and her opening credits theme song. Conceived on set, with Parton using her acrylic nails to clack out the rhythm in her dressing room, the song â€˜9 to 5â€™ is a long way from country. Itâ€™s a buoyant pep talk for exhausted working stiffs, rolling blues, pop and disco into a shot of espresso to get any miserable desk jockey out of bed in the morning.â€”Matthew Singer

30. â€œWhen Doves Cryâ€ by Prince (Purple Rain, 1984)

Twenty-six years old and at the peak of his purple pomp and power, Prince Rogers Nelson not only managed to write this stone-cold classic track in a single night, he also recorded and produced the whole thing single-handedly. A radical sound (baroque synths, slamming drum machine and a gaping void where the bassline should be) and ultravivid lyrics based on the stupendously vain Purple Rain plot made it the biggest-selling single of 1984. Even covers by Ginuwine and Damien Rice havenâ€™t killed its strange allure.â€”James Manning

29. â€œA View to a Killâ€ by Duran Duran (A View to a Kill, 1985)

The James Bond franchise has always had a knack for memorable songs, and you could argue that Duran Duranâ€™s theme for A View to a Killâ€”the 14th film in the series, and the last to feature Roger Mooreâ€”was the best thing about an adventure flick otherwise afflicted by a superannuated leading man, Christopher Walkenâ€™s looney scenery-munching, and two of the dimmest Bond girls ever in Tanya Roberts and Grace Jones. Despite all that, hearing John Taylorâ€™s basslines pop in surround sound was worth the cost of admission.â€”Steve Smith

Advertising

28. â€œManiacâ€ by Michael Sembello (Flashdance, 1983)

Okay, Flashdance checklist time: Jennifer Beals in spandex? Present and correct. Montage of vigorous dance training (and butt shaking) ready to go? Affirmative. All we need now is the ultimate fast-paced, smooth disco song to set it all off. Step forward, Mr. Michael Sembello, with this cowbell-tickling beauty. Sembello actually has a great pedigree as a musicianâ€”he played with Stevie Wonder as a teen, then later with Donna Summer, the Temptations, Michael Jackson and more. The world, however, will only remember him as the guy that soundtracked the ass gymnastics of Jennifer Beals. Iâ€™m sure heâ€™s okay with that.â€”Oliver Keens

27. â€œPretty in Pinkâ€ by the Psychedelic Furs (Pretty in Pink, 1986)

If youâ€™re going to make a movie in which your protagonist works at an oh-so-hip indie record store, you better make sure the soundtrack is equally cool. The accompanying album for this Molly Ringwald vehicle was filled with tunes by cult Brit faves like New Order and the Smiths. Though OMDâ€™s â€œIf You Leaveâ€ is the more enduring hit, the Psychedelic Fursâ€™ tune (for which the movie was named) is the better song if you, like Ringwaldâ€™s Andie, ever felt like a weirdo and an outcast. (Letâ€™s just forget that Andie hooks up with Andrew McCarthyâ€™s cool guy and pretend that she stayed weird and kept working at Trax forever, okay? Okay.)â€”Amy Plitt

Advertising

26. â€œPeople Are Strangeâ€ by Echo & the Bunnymen (The Lost Boys, 1987)

Gloomy Brit rockers Echo & the Bunnymen were, in retrospect, a perfect choice for this cover: The bandâ€™s faithful-but-sorta-gothy rendition of the Doorsâ€™ 1967 hit set the right tone for The Lost Boysâ€™ opening credits, which show the freaks and hippies and punksâ€”and, ominously, missing childrenâ€”that occupy the fictional town of Santa Carla, California. The tune was produced by original Doors member Ray Manzarek, which is the only explanation for the extended (and, ahem, unnecessary) keyboard jam in the middle of the song.â€”Amy Plitt

25. â€œUp Where We Belongâ€ by Joe Cocker and Jennifer Warnes (An Officer and a Gentleman, 1982)

Pairing beautiful actors Richard Gere and Debra Winger in a smoldering romantic drama amounts to a no-brainer, so it's no surprise that An Officer and a Gentleman amounted to big box office. But there's no denying that a big part of the film's impact came from the unlikely "Beauty and the Beast"â€“style teaming of boozy English howler Joe Cocker (best known in 1982 from John Belushi's mimickry) and gently yodeling American cult-favorite singer Jennifer Warnes, in a sentimental ballad by all-star tunesmiths Jack Nitzsche, Buffy Sainte-Marie and Will Jennings. "The song is no good. It isn't a hit," film producer Don Simpson said, but history begged to differ. â€”Steve Smith

Advertising

24. â€œSheâ€™s Like the Windâ€ by Patrick Swayze (Dirty Dancing, 1987)

Young minds will accept a lot of incomprehensible nonsense in the name of a good pop song, but was there a single teen who heard the first line of this song and didnâ€™t do a double take: â€œSheâ€™s like the windâ€¦through my tree.â€ What? Really? Huh. I mean, I guessâ€¦ Dirty Dancing star Patrick Swayze contributed this song to the movie that soundtracked a billion prepubescent girlsâ€™ fantasies of what romance could be. Did it matter that the sheeny â€™80s arrangement of the song was totally anachronistic to the filmâ€™s 1960s setting? Of course not. All that mattered was that Johnny was driving away while Baby cried. On YouTube, this is titled â€œDirty Dancing sad scene.â€ Were truer words ever spoken?â€”Sophie Harris

23. â€œEverybody Wants to Rule the Worldâ€ by Tears for Fears (Real Genius, 1985)

Tears for Fearsâ€™ career peak, this spent two weeks at No. 1 in America in the first summer of Reaganâ€™s second term, two months before the movie hit. The riff is the themeâ€”chiming beach guitars that lead into two doomy keyboard chords. It lent an air of Cold War dread to a lighthearted college comedy that ends by condemning the military industrial complexâ€™s exploitation of science. Thanks to Val Kilmer, indoor waterslides, laser-cooked popcorn, secret subdormitory lairs and this song, the movie showed that nerds can be cool and puckish.â€”Brent DiCrescenzo

Advertising

22. â€œI Melt With Youâ€ by Modern English (Valley Girl, 1983)

Ah, back to the days when Nic Cage was a (believable) hunky male lead and â€œfalling in loveâ€ montages were, like, totally a thing. British new-wavers Modern English released this one-hit wonder in 1982, and a year laterâ€”after reaching No. 7 on Billboardâ€™s Top Tracks and getting decent airplay on MTVâ€”it became Valley Girlâ€™s romantic ballad, helping us believe in love between a pastel-pink Val gal and a punk-rock city slicker. The lyrics describe a couple making love as nuclear bombs fall, which we think Randy would have been pretty into. Fer sure.â€”Kate Wertheimer

21. â€œDanger Zoneâ€ by Kenny Loggins (Top Gun, 1986)

Loggins continued his soundtrack streak, which included hits from Caddyshack and Footloose, with this fist-pumper from Top Gun. Used in the filmâ€™s opening scene, â€œDanger Zoneâ€ sets the tone for whatâ€™s to follow: lots of aerodynamic stunts, confrontations between hotheaded dudes and a whole lot of jingoistic fervor. Reportedly, the filmâ€™s success led to a bump in Navy recruitmentâ€”no big surprise, since it looks like one big commercial for the armed forces.â€”Amy Plitt

10. â€œIf You Leaveâ€ by Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark (Pretty in Pink, 1986)

Itâ€™s a classic prom-DJ rookie mistake: playing the same song over and over again on a seemingly endless loop. But if the formal faux pas must be made, as it is during the climactic scenes of the 1986 John Hughesâ€“written Cinderella story, Pretty in Pink, let the song be the yearning, melancholic, yet totally danceable â€œIf You Leave,â€ by British new-wavers OMD. After all, whether your date is a Blane or a Duckie, there is no better setting than the prom to make this impassioned plea: â€œPromise me just one more night, then weâ€™ll go our separate ways.â€ Score!â€”Michael Chen

9. â€œSt. Elmoâ€™s Fire (Man in Motion)â€ by John Parr (St. Elmoâ€™s Fire, 1985)

Watch the Brat Packers ache beautifully: Rob Lowe, adorned with a sax strap but no instrument, canâ€™t put his horndogging ways behind him. Demi Moore is too coked-up to avoid sleeping with married men. And Judd Nelson has to somehow become okay with being Judd Nelson. How dazzling, then, that given these specific psychological issues, a perfect theme song was found in an anthem written months earlier, for wheelchair-bound Canadian athlete Rick Hansen, the original â€œman in motion.â€ Two-hit wonder John Parr moaned the lyrics, but the schmaltz should be properly credited to composer David Foster, who never kicked a cheesy synth-trumpet sound out of bed for eating crackers.â€”Joshua Rothkopf

Advertising

8. â€œTake My Breath Awayâ€ by Berlin (Top Gun, 1986)

Tom Cruise, having already bonked Rebecca De Mornay on a Chicago El train to the strains of Phil Collins in Risky Business, mounts Kelly McGillis in soft blue light to the erotic keyboard riff of Berlinâ€™s Oscar winner. The L.A. band finally earned its name, working with a titan of the German discotheque scene. Giorgio Moroderâ€”the genius behind cinematic classics like Blondieâ€™s â€œCall Me,â€ â€œThe NeverEnding Story,â€ â€œChaseâ€ and moreâ€”slow-jams it down to the point where the synth-bass line twangs like a Japanese shamisen. Itâ€™s hard to believe this is the man who made â€œI Feel Love.â€ Much like itâ€™s hard to believe Top Gun director Tony Scott shot this jingoist flick after The Hunger, which spun MTV and advertising editing techniques into abstract gothic art. Not only can pioneering artists make sex-glossed pop for the masses, they do it better than the rest.â€”Brent DiCrescenzo

7. â€œPurple Rainâ€ by Prince (Purple Rain, 1984)

The album that accompanied His Purplenessâ€™s 1984 flick isnâ€™t merely a good soundtrack; itâ€™s one of the most innovative records of the past few decadesâ€”maybe even of all time. Miraculously, the Academy Awards recognized that tooâ€”the album earned the Best Original Song Score Oscar in 1985. (To accept the award, Prince wore a sparkly purple cape, and brought Lisa and Wendy with him to the stage. Of course.) The title ballad provides the filmâ€™s climactic moment, when Princeâ€™s character, the Kid, realizes his potential (with the help of Lisa and Wendy, who, in the filmâ€™s lore, provided the songâ€™s inspiration), and becomes a star.â€”Amy Plitt

Advertising

6. â€œIn Your Eyesâ€ by Peter Gabriel (Say Anythingâ€¦, 1989)

If there exists a more indelible image of a pining lover trying to get through to a former flame than the sight of John Cusack as Lloyd Dobler, boom box hoisted overhead to reach Ione Skyeâ€™s Diane Court, then we have yet to see it. Instrumental in transforming Peter Gabriel from art-rock loon to adult-rock sophisticate, â€œIn Your Eyesâ€ got an added touch of swoonworthy oomph from Youssou Nâ€™Dourâ€™s soaring support vocals.â€”Steve Smith

5. â€œ(Iâ€™ve Had) The Time of My Lifeâ€ by Bill Medley and Jennifer Warnes (Dirty Dancing, 1987)

Before the sex scene that launched a thousand suburban pottery studios, Patrick Swayze made our hearts throb as misunderstood dance instructor Johnny Castle in this young-love story. The duet soundtracks the movieâ€™s finale, its lyrics standing in for dialogue while Johnny and Baby say it all with their eyes and their hips. At the first chorus, even the dancing stops for a momentâ€”all action is suspended as Medley and Warnesâ€™s voices take center stage. The sweetest moment hits just after the five minute mark, when Swayze actually mouths the words to the song, just like your actual boyfriend would.â€”Sarah Theeboom

Advertising

4. â€œFootlooseâ€ by Kenny Loggins (Footloose, 1984)

The Mount Rushmore of 1980s movie songwriters looks like this: Kenny Loggins, Kenneth Loggins, Ken â€œThe Logâ€ Loggins, Kenny freakinâ€™ Loggins. After dumping â€™70s yacht-folk songwriting partner Jim Messina, this son of the American West Coast trimmed his beard, teased his mullet and went mainstream pop. â€œIâ€™m Alrightâ€ in Caddyshack. â€œPlaying with the Boys,â€ from the homoerotic volleyball scene in Top Gun. And his apex, â€œFootloose.â€ A jumped-up, plastic rockabilly lick powers this gleefully dumb shuffle, which soundtracked Kevin Baconâ€™s grudge-dancing in an empty barn, a classic cheeseball musical montage of choreographed frustration that would later be applied to detention (The Breakfast Club), skateboarding (Gleaming the Cube) and groin stretching (Bloodsport).â€”Brent DiCrescenzo

3. â€œThe Power of Loveâ€ by Huey Lewis and the News (Back to the Future, 1985)
